ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I didn't learn anything, as no instructor guidance or teaching was provided.

This course was a free-form math course designed to prepare students for the Putnam exam. I was exposed to areas of mathematics and problem solving techniques I had never seen, and ultimately learned a variety of useful math, particularly number theory and discrete math.
Putnam stuff!
I learned about competition math problems and the techniques used to solve them.
This course exposed me to problem-solving strategies and proofs in math I hadn't encountered before. I feel much more confident in approaching unfamiliar problems from our group work in this course.

You will walk through and explore a lot of different topics covered in competition math (Putnam). A good refresher for past olympiad competitors and a good start for those interested in thinking in a different way than from standard math classes.
Many problem solving strategies for competitive math starting from induction and basic problems for beginners.
Many different Math problem solving skills!
I just got better at thinking about math and approaching open-ended problems.
Mathematical Problem solving
fun and easy!
You learn how to write proofs for the Putnam exam.
I learned how to solve Putnam-type problems.
Worked on Putnam style problems in a fun groupwork type seminar.
Some tips and tricks that help with Putnam type questions.
I learned advanced problem solving techniques and how to begin to write proofs.
This course allowed me to hone my proof-writing skills and gave me the opportunity to participate in a math tournament for the second time ever.
I learned some problem solving skills, and found a reason to do more contest math in a classroom setting. It was exactly what I was looking for in preparation for the Putnam.
Not much tbh... I guess I improved my math skills a bit.
Great intro to proof-based math!
Mathematical problem-solving, especially finding creative solutions to strange problems.
Experience taking the Putnam exam and similar exams.
I improved my mathematical problem-solving skills by being given many Putnam problems to work on.
competition-style problem solving
Proof solving abilities
cool math strategies
Proofs, number theory, etc. and math tricks.
Critical Putnam skills, problem-solving skills, and general math aptitude.
Lots of questions covering various topics present on the Putnam exam
Good survey of competition math topics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I would appreciate a little more structure, particularly if at the beginning of each class the instructor would talk briefly about the topic of the day instead of just letting us dive into the problems.
This year, there wasn't really any instruction at all. I think this should be a full credit course with real lectures in addition to problem solving sessions.
Pretty fun and relaxed class where you work on math problems with friends. Take it only if you are interested in competition math, not for a easy credit though.
Strength: instructor, interesting topics, low time commitment Weaknesses: meetings on Tuesday evenings, weekly homeworks

Solving problems in groups is a great asset of this course. Persistence through difficult problems was strong in our groups, and having others with whom to explore/grapple with concepts was instrumental to my learning.

I enjoyed it most of the time. In my opinion the questions that were presented could be more representative of the Putnam, because of this the questions became more about sudden inspiration, whereas the Putnam is about exploration. All in all I think there should be more emphasis on fewer problems during the class with additional materials for after/during the week.

You get as much out of this class as you put in, which is a good thing. If you're having a hard week, this class adds no more stress. But if you have some extra time some week and want to spend it doing fun math problems, this class gives you that opportunity.
It was exactly what it was meant to be, practice for the Putnam by simply doing lots of problems
interesting content!
I wish there was more instruction. I had never done proofs and just wished that 75% of the class time was used doing example problems as a class. I felt very lost.

We did lots of practice problems, and the homeworks reinforced our in-class themes. But there was very little "learning" in each class beyond doing practice problems, and I would have appreciated a more guided/hands-on approach to the material.
Essentially a problem solving seminar for a half credit. Pretty well structured and Pat is awesome.

Strengths: It's a fun way to get a half credit and to get yourself to take the Putman. Weaknesses: Because it's largely self-/peer-study, you don't learn much. It would be great if there could be a lecture component to the course in which real skills are taught.
More teacher engagement would be nice.
It's great because you can practice writing proofs and working with math in an environment of smart and supportive people!
Group work is a strength. A weakness is everyone is coming at this class from different backgrounds and with different intentions so sometimes theres an imbalance.
Really fun - it's a great way to hang out with both math and non-math folks alike!
It was generally very good.

The strengths of this course include a wide array of problems to work on and a supportive community of math problem-solvers who are eager to work on them. However, solutions to problems were often not given, and students had to find them online themselves. I think it would be better for the instructor to give solutions to key problems and explain why they are instructive.
The instructor was the best aspect of this course, he really cared about teaching us
I really liked it as is! Actually would not change anything - I liked how chill the class was as it allowed people at different abilities to be doing different things

The course is good- dividing up its class into those who are very much interested in math and those who are looking for an interesting half-credit course. We could have perhaps gone over more problems as class before being left to try problems on our own.
Strengths - low time commitment, fun class Weaknesses - still felt a bit unprepared for the Putnam, but you can never be fully prepared anyway

The non-math major / math major divide of rooms seemed somewhat exclusive - I never got to know the students in the other room. Maybe a larger room would be more helpful for the administration of the course if possible or some switching of the rooms

The course did really well in catering to different math backgrounds, and offered a good variety of problems every week. It could improve by offering a solution guide/hints to previous weeks' problem sets.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, this course provides no benefit to the students and is used only as a way to boost Yale student participation in the Putnam Exam, for which this class does not prepare individuals.
I would absolutely recommend this to anyone who is at all interested in math, as it is available to all levels of mathematical ability.
Yes
The class is definitely going to be different next time it's taught, so it's not really worth reading reviews
If you are taking the Putnam, sure why not?
Only for mathies who would like to do well on the Putnam.
Absolutely. A fantastic, low-pressure opportunity to engage with (and enjoy!) math particularly if you aren't in the major.
Again if you want to do better on the Putnam or if you're interested in doing math with other people, do it.
I'd highly recommend this course to anyone who's interested in learning techniques about competitive math, and having a less stressful course.
Anybody interested in Math based proofs should take this course!

Definitely. This course is extremely flexible, so it's easy to tailor how much work you do from week to week depending on the workload for the rest of your classes. Even if you don't put much work into the class, at the end of the semester you come out with a packet of fun math problems to do on your own and the experience of participating in the Putnam.

Why not? It's fun, you get to meet other math students and practice fun math problems, and at the end of it you can take a university-level math competition. Pat will become your fun uncle and you get an extra half credit to top-up that 4.5 you had to take for the language requirement. Plus there will probably be some free food at some point. Again, why not?
If you need a half credit and want to spend an extra few hours a week on fun math problems, :)
ya
It is a good course. You might not learn a lot if you are not a math major.
If you want to take the Putnam, for sure!

Fun seminar to do Putnam problems for a half credit, pass fail. Homework is just scanning in a solutions, so essentially nothing. You have to take the Putnam which I guess is work, but why take the class if you have no interest in taking it anyways. Lots of fun, and Pat is the best.
Yes, it's a chill way to do some fun math even if you know you have no chance of doing well on the Putnam.
Yes, this course was extremely fun and rewarding when you solve a problem!
Yes! It's a great course if you're thinking about math, or if you are even just curious about it. It's super low-stakes and laid back.
Yes if you are interested in doing more contest math.
If you need a half credit sure.
Yes! It's a ton of fun and you'll actually learn some cool proof strategies!
For sure! Chill and you learn a bit, if not just get some practice in.
Yes
Yeah!

I would recommend this course to any student who is seeking to improve their mathematical problem-solving skills because it is a low commitment class that exemplifies the "you get what you put in" mantra of learning.
If you need a half credit to graduate or round up your credit count take this.
Absolutely, riveting material
Absolutely yes Pat is an absolute gem and the course/work is a lot of fun.

Unless you actually have a chance of doing good on the Putnam before taking this class, it might not be much help. Take it if you think you want it, but if you have no expectation of doing well, then it may be a drag.
Yup, definitely! As long as that student liked math in some way

If you need a half credit that meets once a week, yes, please take it. It's like a crash course in proofs and number theory- the weekly homework is to attempt 2 problems we looked at in class (they're not graded, you just have to do it) and there is no final exam. You will be required to take the famed Putnam Exam at the end of the semester, but it's a really great course! Pat is a wonderful teacher. Very fun to learn from and very, very good at explaining mathematical concepts. Thank you, Pat!
Yes! Great half-credit course that isnt too much of a time commitment, and you learn a bunch!
It was fun! It felt more like a club than a course. Take it with friends!
Yes! Take the Putnam too :)

Yes, I think this would be a great course to take regardless if you're interested in the Putnam or not. It introduces simple concepts and shows how they can be used to solve a lot of cool and complicated problems.
